chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: This is a download from BBC Learning English. To find out more, visit our website.

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: I hate crowds. But you love going to the football match on Saturday. Well, that's different. More like a big group of friends. Well, whether it's sporting events, train stations or political protests, crowds – that's large groups of people who gather together for a shared activity – are a feature of life. For some, crowds create feelings of excitement and a sense of community, while for others they feel uncomfortable, confusing or even

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: dangerous. So why is that? In this programme we'll be discussing the role of crowds in modern life, asking why they evoke different reactions in people. And as usual, we'll be learning some new vocabulary as well. But first, I have a question for you, Neil. The biggest crowd in history happened in 2019 when over 200 million people gathered in the northern Indian city of Allahabad. But what did so many people come together for? Was it a...

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: a cricket match, be a religious festival or see an election? Well, I know Indians love cricket but I doubt 200 million people would fit into a stadium, so I'll guess it's see an election. OK, Neil. We'll find out the answer later in the programme. People gathering for a cricket match or a music concert are usually happy events. But crowds can have a darker side as well. They can become out of control and sometimes even violent.

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: Here's psychologist Professor John Drury discussing this idea with Anand Jagatia, presenter of the BBC World Service programme, appropriately named Crowdscience. When people get together in a crowd, they regress psychologically, their thinking is more primitive, they become more gullible. And that's also associated with a supposed tendency towards violence as well. But according to John, the idea of mob mentality, that people in crowds are irrational,

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: and prone to destructive behaviour, just isn't backed up by research.

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: But according to Professor Drury, in reality it's not mob mentality and violence, but rather feelings of safety and togetherness that actually characterise crowds. And according to Dr Anne Templeton, another expert on crowd psychology from the University of Edinburgh,

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: that's especially true when you identify with the other people in a crowd. Here's Dr Templeton explaining more to BBC World Service programme, Crowdscience.

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: The flip side of that is when you don't feel as much part of the group and you're not having as positive experience. Dr Templeton thinks there is a correlation, that's a connection or a link between being among people who share your values and feeling safe. Football fans cheer their team on by wearing the same colours and singing the same songs and this works as a kind of glue, bonding the crowd together and making them feel safe.

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: In today's world, crowds are important because of the feeling of power they give us.

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: Right. In my question, I asked you why 200 million people gathered in the Indian city of Allahabad in 2019. I guessed it was to vote in an election, was I right? You were wrong, I'm afraid, Neil. In fact, the biggest crowd in history had gathered for a Hindu religious festival, the Kambh Mela, which 220 million people attended over 50 days. OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned from this programme on crowds.

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: Large numbers of people who gather together for a shared reason. To regress means return to less advanced, more primitive behaviours. Regress is the opposite of progress. Someone who is gullible is easily tricked and will believe anything people say. The phrase mob mentality describes the tendency of people in a group to behave in ways that conform with others in the group rather than as individuals.

chunks.episode_title: Are you lonely in a crowd_
chunks.chunk_text: And finally, the flip side of something means those aspects of it which are less obvious, good or pleasant. The flip side of this programme is that once again our 6 minutes are up. Bye for now. Bye bye.
